training.sample: For example, someone with severe agoraphobia may be unable to leave the house, whereas someone who has mild agoraphobia may be able to travel short distances without problems.SYMPTOM(127,131)agoraphobia1.0SYMPTOM(33,44)agoraphobia1.0social phobia0.0SYMPTOM(108,119)agoraphobia1.0social phobia0.0

Antisocial personality disorder is a particularly challenging type of personality disorder characterised by impulsive, irresponsible and often criminal behaviour.SYMPTOM(108,117)personality disorder1.0SYMPTOM(143,161)personality disorder1.0

Carbamazepine and lithium may help control symptoms such as aggression and impulsive behaviour, and a class of antidepressant called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may improve anger and general personality disorder symptoms.SYMPTOM(85,94)agoraphobia0.0personality disorder0.5personality disorder, antisocial0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0disorder0.5shocked0.0SYMPTOM(75,84)personality disorder1.0SYMPTOM(193,198)antisocial personality disorder0.0personality disorder1.0

For example, a person with borderline personality disorder (one of the most common types) tends to have disturbed ways of thinking, impulsive behaviour and problems controlling their emotions.SYMPTOM(142,151)agoraphobia0.0personality disorder0.5personality disorder, antisocial0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0disorder0.5shocked0.0SYMPTOM(132,141)personality disorder1.0

Like other types of personality disorder, antisocial personality disorder is on a spectrum, which means it can range in severity from occasional bad behaviour to repeatedly breaking the law and committing serious crimes.SYMPTOM(149,158)agoraphobia0.0personality disorder0.2personality disorder, antisocial0.2antisocial personality disorder0.2disorder0.2shocked0.0

The Mind website has more information about signs of antisocial personality disorder.SYMPTOM(44,49)eating disorder0.0antisocial personality disorder1.0binge eating disorder0.0bulimia0.0abuse0.0blood0.0depression0.0
A person with antisocial personality disorder may lack concern, regret or remorse about other people's distress.SYMPTOM(103,111)antisocial personality disorder1.0anxiety disorders0.0
A person with antisocial personality disorder may behave irresponsibly and show disregard for normal social behaviour.SYMPTOM(94,117)antisocial personality disorder1.0
A person with antisocial personality disorder may be unable to control their anger.SYMPTOM(77,82)antisocial personality disorder0.5personality disorder0.5

A person with antisocial personality disorder will typically get easily frustrated and have difficulty controlling their anger.SYMPTOM(121,126)antisocial personality disorder0.5personality disorder0.5SYMPTOM(72,82)antisocial personality disorder1.0
A person with antisocial personality disorder may lack guilt, or not learn from their mistakes.SYMPTOM(55,60)antisocial personality disorder1.0

A person with antisocial personality disorder will have a history of conduct disorder during childhood, such as truancy (not going to school), delinquency (for example, committing crimes or substance misuse), and other disruptive and aggressive behaviours.SYMPTOM(93,102)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5dissociative disorder0.0abuse0.0personality disorders0.0depression0.0SYMPTOM(112,119)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5

It's not known why some people develop antisocial personality disorder, but both genetics and traumatic childhood experiences, such as child abuse or neglect, are thought to play a role.SYMPTOM(104,113)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.0dissociative disorder0.0abuse0.5personality disorders0.0depression0.0SYMPTOM(135,146)antisocial personality disorder1.0SYMPTOM(150,157)antisocial personality disorder0.5abuse0.5personality disorders0.0SYMPTOM(174,178)antisocial personality disorder1.0severe depression0.0

A person with antisocial personality disorder will have a history of conduct disorder during childhood, such as truancy (not going to school), delinquency (for example, committing crimes or substance misuse), and other disruptive and no aggressive behaviours.SYMPTOM(93,102)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5dissociative disorder0.0abuse0.0personality disorders0.0depression0.0SYMPTOM(112,119)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5SYMPTOM(234,258)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5

A person with antisocial personality disorder will have a history of conduct disorder during childhood, such as truancy (not going to school), no delinquency (for example, committing crimes or substance misuse), and other disruptive and no aggressive behaviours.SYMPTOM(93,102)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5dissociative disorder0.0abuse0.0personality disorders0.0depression0.0SYMPTOM(112,119)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5SYMPTOM(237,261)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5SYMPTOM(143,157)antisocial personality disorder0.5conduct disorder0.5

Criminal behaviour is a key feature of antisocial personality disorder, and there's a high risk that someone with the disorder will commit crimes and be imprisoned at some point in their life.SYMPTOM(9,18)agoraphobia0.0personality disorder0.3personality disorder, antisocial0.0antisocial personality disorder0.3disorder0.3shocked0.0SYMPTOM(153,163)antisocial personality disorder0.5disorder0.5SYMPTOM(86,90)antisocial personality disorder0.5disorder0.5postpartum psychosis0.0postnatal psychosis0.0mania0.0

People with antisocial personality disorder are also more likely to have relationship problems during adulthood and be unemployed and homeless.SYMPTOM(119,129)antisocial personality disorder1.0SYMPTOM(73,94)antisocial personality disorder1.0schizophrenia0.0SYMPTOM(134,142)antisocial personality disorder1.0

To be diagnosed with antisocial personality disorder, a person will usually have a history of conduct personality disorder before the age of 15.SYMPTOM(94,101)personality disorder0.5antisocial personality disorder0.5

During a period of depression, your symptoms may include loss of interest in everyday activities.SYMPTOM(57,73)depression1.0
During a period of depression, your symptoms may include feelings of guilt and despair.SYMPTOM(79,86)depression1.0SYMPTOM(57,74)depression1.0
During a period of depression, your symptoms may include feeling pessimistic about everything.SYMPTOM(65,76)depression1.0
During a period of depression, your symptoms may include self-doubt.SYMPTOM(57,67)depression1.0

The manic phase of bipolar disorder may include feeling very happy, elated or overjoyed.SYMPTOM(61,66)bipolar disorder1.0SYMPTOM(68,74)bipolar disorder1.0postnatal psychosis0.0mania0.0SYMPTOM(4,9)bipolar disorder1.0
The manic phase of bipolar disorder may include being easily distracted.SYMPTOM(4,9)bipolar disorder1.0SYMPTOM(54,71)bipolar disorder1.0
The manic phase of bipolar disorder may include being easily irritated or agitated.SYMPTOM(4,9)bipolar disorder1.0SYMPTOM(74,82)bipolar disorder1.0

The manic phase of bipolar disorder may include being delusional, having hallucinations and disturbed or illogical thinking.SYMPTOM(105,123)depression0.0bipolar disorder1.0SYMPTOM(73,87)depression0.0bipolar disorder1.0postpartum psychosis0.0schizophrenia0.0SYMPTOM(4,9)bipolar disorder1.0

The patterns are not always the same and some people may experience rapid cycling â€“ where a person with bipolar disorder repeatedly swings from a no high to a low phase quickly without having a "normal" period in between.SYMPTOM(146,153)bipolar disorder1.0

The patterns are not always the same and some people may experience mixed state â€“ where a person with bipolar disorder experiences symptoms of depression and mania together; for example, overactivity with a no depressed mood.SYMPTOM(207,224)depression0.3bipolar disorder0.3mania0.3

If your mood swings last a long time but are not severe enough to be classed as bipolar disorder, you may be diagnosed with a mild form of bipolar disorder called no cyclothymia.SYMPTOM(8,19)disorder0.5bipolar disorder0.5dissociative disorder0.0SYMPTOM(163,177)bipolar disorder1.0

After the episode is over, they may be shocked at their behaviour.SYMPTOM(56,65)agoraphobia0.0personality disorder0.0personality disorder, antisocial0.0antisocial personality disorder0.0disorder0.0shocked1.0

Previous case reports of FII have uncovered evidence of parents or carers deliberately contaminating or manipulating clinical tests to fake evidence of illness, for example, by adding blood or sugar to urine samples.SYMPTOM(152,159)abuse0.0blood1.0cystic fibrosis0.0leukaemia0.0
Previous case reports of FII have uncovered evidence of parents or carers poisoning their child with unsuitable and non-prescribed medicine.SYMPTOM(90,95)blood0.0poisoning1.0wounds0.0autism0.0

Previous case reports of FII have uncovered evidence of parents or carers infecting their child's wounds or injecting the child with dirt or poo.SYMPTOM(90,95)blood0.0poisoning0.0wounds1.0autism0.0SYMPTOM(122,127)blood0.0poisoning0.0wounds1.0autism0.0

A hoarding disorder is where someone acquires an excessive number of items and stores them in a chaotic manner, usually resulting in unmanageable amounts of clutter.SYMPTOM(2,10)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0SYMPTOM(157,164)disorder1.0dementia0.0SYMPTOM(146,153)disorder1.0dementia0.0

Most people with a hoarding disorder have a very strong emotional attachment to the objects.SYMPTOM(19,27)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically keep or collect items that may have little or no monetary value, such as junk mail and carrier bags, or items they intend to reuse or repair.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically find it hard to categorise or organise items.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically have difficulty making decisions.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0SYMPTOM(55,82)disorder1.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically struggle to manage everyday tasks, such as cooking, cleaning and paying bills.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically become extremely attached to items, refusing to let anyone touch or borrow them.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Someone who has a hoarding disorder may typically have poor relationships with family or friends.SYMPTOM(18,26)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0

Some people with a hoarding disorder will hoard a range of items, while others may just hoard certain types of objects.SYMPTOM(19,27)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0SYMPTOM(42,47)disorders0.0disorder1.0SYMPTOM(88,93)disorders0.0disorder1.0

A hoarding disorder can be a problem for several reasons.SYMPTOM(2,10)disorder1.0severe depression0.0schizophrenia0.0psychotic disorders0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0disorders0.0depression0.0dementia0.0SYMPTOM(29,36)disorders0.0disorder1.0

Hoarding disorders are challenging to treat because many people who hoard frequently do not see it as a no problem, or have little awareness of how it's affecting their life or the lives of others.SYMPTOM(104,114)disorders1.0SYMPTOM(68,73)disorders0.5disorder0.5

For example, someone with mobility problems may be physically unable to clear the huge amounts of clutter they have acquired, and people with learning disabilities or people developing dementia may be unable to categorise and dispose of items.SYMPTOM(98,105)disorder0.0dementia1.0SYMPTOM(87,94)disorder0.0dementia1.0SYMPTOM(151,163)dementia1.0

It is the additional anxiety about panic combined with catastrophic cognitions in the face of panic that differentiate between the person with panic disorder and the occasional nonclinical panicker (e.g., Telch, Lucas, & Nelson, 1989) or the person with other anxiety disorders who also happens to panic.SYMPTOM(21,28)depression0.0dissociative disorder0.0dementia0.0personality disorders0.0panic disorder0.5psychoses0.0mood disorders0.0anxiety disorders0.5personality disorder0.0obsessive compulsive disorder0.0social phobia0.0SYMPTOM(35,40)panic disorder0.2anxiety disorders0.2generalized anxiety disorder0.0disorder0.2anxiety disorder0.2SYMPTOM(94,99)panic disorder0.2anxiety disorders0.2generalized anxiety disorder0.0disorder0.2anxiety disorder0.2SYMPTOM(298,303)panic disorder0.2anxiety disorders0.2generalized anxiety disorder0.0disorder0.2anxiety disorder0.2

Other typical symptoms of severe depression are thoughts of death or suicide.SYMPTOM(60,65)severe depression1.0

The physical symptoms of depression include changes in appetite or weight (usually decreased, but sometimes increased).SYMPTOM(44,63)severe depression0.0depression1.0SYMPTOM(108,117)depression1.0

The symptoms of schizophrenia are usually classified into positive symptoms â€“ any change in behaviour or thoughts, such as hallucinations or delusions.SYMPTOM(123,137)depression0.0bipolar disorder0.0postpartum psychosis0.0schizophrenia1.0SYMPTOM(141,150)postpartum psychosis0.0schizophrenia1.0SYMPTOM(82,101)schizophrenia1.0

The symptoms of schizophrenia are usually classified into negative symptoms â€“ where people appear to withdraw from the world around then, take no interest in everyday social interactions, and often appear emotionless and flat.SYMPTOM(143,154)depression0.0schizophrenia1.0
Research using brain-scanning equipment shows changes in the speech area in the brains of people with schizophrenia when they hear voices.SYMPTOM(126,137)schizophrenia1.0

Negative symptoms experienced by people living with schizophrenia include losing interest and motivation in life and activities, including relationships and sex.SYMPTOM(94,104)schizophrenia1.0SYMPTOM(81,89)schizophrenia1.0
Negative symptoms experienced by people living with schizophrenia include lack of concentration, not wanting to leave the house, and changes in sleeping patterns.SYMPTOM(74,95)schizophrenia1.0

The negative symptoms of schizophrenia can often lead to relationship problems with friends and family as they can sometimes be mistaken for deliberate laziness or rudeness.SYMPTOM(57,78)antisocial personality disorder0.0schizophrenia1.0
In addition to symptoms of depression, you may also feel lethargic (lacking in energy) and sleepy during the day.SYMPTOM(68,85)depression1.0SYMPTOM(57,66)depression1.0SYMPTOM(91,97)depression1.0
